Description: Solid-cast figure of Mahes (or Mihos), son of Bastet in copper alloy; the lion-headed male deity is depicted standing, in a striding pose, on a thin base, with his hand on both sides along his body; wearing a short kilt and the Atef crown, composed of the white crown flanked by two ostrich feathers and possibly with uraeus on front; suspension loop to the back of his head, so might have been used as an amulet; well preserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This figure belongs to the type 106 in the typology of figure bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 201-202, 666-669, Pl. 29 a-d, Pl. 73, Typ 106). Bronze figures of Mahes were mainly discovered in Leontopolis and Bubastis where his cult as the son of Bastet was the most dynamic. A second bronze figure of Mahes, larger and fragmentary, was discovered during the first season of excavations in Naukratis, BM1885, 1101.84. It originates from the cache of bronzes (on this cache and content: Petrie 1886, 41-42; Masson 2015). It is not the case of this figure which was discovered later in Naukratis. K. Weiss (in Weiss 2012, 896, Nr. 1451) states that E.A. 683-687 corresponds to five figures of Apis; however, these registration numbers correspond to various glazed composition amulets and this bronze amuletic figure of Mahes, none features a bull. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
